statement.text: Medial visceral rotation (MVR) provides exposure to the entire abdominal aorta and iliac vessels by mobilizing the abdominal viscera medially. Left MVR (Mattox maneuver) rotates the left colon, kidney, spleen, and pancreas to expose the aorta from the hiatus to the bifurcation. Right MVR (Cattell-Braasch maneuver) mobilizes the right colon and duodenum to expose the IVC, right renal vessels, and right iliac system. These maneuvers are essential for major aortic trauma, thoracoabdominal aneurysm repair, and complex aortic reconstructions.
statement.formal: MVR Left (Mattox): Incise white line of Toldt → Mobilize left colon, kidney, spleen, pancreas tail medially → Expose aorta from hiatus to bifurcation | MVR Right (Cattell-Braasch): Kocher maneuver + mobilize right colon → Expose IVC, right renal vessels | Applications: Aortic trauma, complex aneurysm repair, suprarenal exposure

explanation.intuition: Imagine the abdominal organs as furniture arranged in a room with the aorta as the main pipe running along the back wall. Medial visceral rotation is like moving all the furniture to one side of the room so you can see and work on the entire pipe from top to bottom. On the left side, you're moving the colon, kidney, and spleen toward the center; on the right side, you're moving the colon and duodenum to see the vena cava.
explanation.key_insight: Left MVR provides the most extensive aortic exposure possible from a transabdominal approach - you can see from the diaphragmatic hiatus to the iliac bifurcation. This is the exposure of choice for a 'zone 1' retroperitoneal hematoma in trauma (supraceliac aorta) because it's fast and comprehensive.
explanation.technical_details: Left MVR Technique: (1) Midline laparotomy; (2) Incise white line of Toldt (peritoneal reflection of left colon); (3) Mobilize left colon medially by blunt dissection in the avascular plane; (4) Continue mobilization to include left kidney (leave Gerota's fascia intact); (5) Mobilize spleen and pancreas tail medially (ligate short gastric vessels if needed); (6) Entire left-sided viscera rotates medially toward midline; (7) Divide left crus of diaphragm for supraceliac exposure. Right MVR Technique: (1) Extended Kocher maneuver - mobilize duodenum and head of pancreas; (2) Incise white line of Toldt on right; (3) Mobilize right colon and small bowel mesentery medially; (4) Exposes IVC, right renal vein, right iliac vessels. Combined: Both maneuvers together provide exposure to the entire retroperitoneum.
common_misconceptions: MVR is only for trauma - it's useful for elective complex aortic surgery too
You must remove the spleen to do left MVR - the spleen rotates with the other organs
The plane is hard to find - it's an avascular plane, should dissect easily
You can't do MVR in a hostile abdomen - adhesions make it harder but often still possible

definitions_glossary.white_line_of_toldt: Peritoneal reflection of the colon, incise to mobilize colon medially
definitions_glossary.mattox_maneuver: Left medial visceral rotation for aortic exposure
definitions_glossary.cattell_braasch_maneuver: Right medial visceral rotation for IVC exposure
definitions_glossary.gerotas_fascia: Perirenal fascia - keep intact during kidney mobilization

indications: Renal artery revascularization requiring extensive exposure
contraindications: Prior retroperitoneal surgery with extensive scarring (relative)
Prior nephrectomy on side of rotation (relative)
Hemodynamic instability requiring faster approach (consider direct supraceliac clamp)

left_mvr.patient_position: Supine, may tilt right side up
steps: Incise white line of Toldt from splenic flexure to sigmoid
Develop avascular plane behind colon by blunt dissection
Continue behind left kidney (leave in Gerota's fascia)
Mobilize spleen by dividing lienocolic and lienorenal ligaments
Divide short gastric vessels if spleen doesn't rotate easily
Rotate entire left visceral mass medially
Expose aorta from hiatus to bifurcation
Divide left crus for supraceliac control if needed
Incise white line of Toldt on right
Expose IVC, right renal vessels, right iliacs

complications.prevention: Gentle handling, divide ligaments before rotating
complications.management: Splenorrhaphy or splenectomy; vaccinate if splenectomy

complications.prevention: Keep tail with spleen, avoid traction on body
complications.management: Drain if injury, may need resection if severe

complications.prevention: Don't twist mesentery, check perfusion before closing

definition.@value: Surgical technique of mobilizing abdominal viscera medially to expose the retroperitoneal great vessels

sources.citation: Mattox KL. Approaches to trauma involving the major vessels of the thorax. Surg Clin North Am. 1989;69(1):77-91.
Rutherford's Vascular Surgery, 9th Edition. Aortic Exposure Techniques.

learning_objectives: Describe the anatomy of medial visceral rotation maneuvers
Perform left MVR (Mattox maneuver) for aortic exposure
Perform right MVR (Cattell-Braasch) for IVC exposure
Select appropriate maneuver based on surgical goals
clinical_pearls: Left MVR is the exposure of choice for zone 1 retroperitoneal hematoma (supraceliac aorta)
The plane behind the colon is avascular - if you're bleeding, you're in the wrong plane
Divide the short gastrics early if you're having trouble rotating the spleen
Don't forget to divide the left crus for supraceliac control
Right MVR gives you IVC exposure - essential for caval injuries or right renal vein
